page.title: 17ROCK FORMATION
page.content: The rocks underlying this area belong to the Ordovician system and were laid down between 500 and 435 million years ago in a sea which was then in existence.The rocks here are mainly mudstones with some bands of sandstone Some beds contain small fossils known as graptolites,and these when they occur , help to date the rocks. The graptolites found indicate the rocks to be near thetop of the Ordovician-in beds named the Lower Bala-now renamed the Caradocian.These very old rocks on low ground are covered by boulder clay formed during the last Ice Age,and was then deposited when the ice melted and retreated northwards-some 10,000 years ago.The clay is found in the form of hummocks or humps, and explains why the roads from Velindre to Pentrecagal and from Drefach to Llangeler have so many 'ups & downs'. {MR.O.T.DAVIES.
